questions.question_text:
A new major project is starting that consists of two interconnected subprojects. One of the subprojects was assigned to a contractor who commits to submitting biweekly status reports and attending weekly integration meetings. Halfway through the project, the contractor stops participating in the meetings and does not submit the reports. Their excuse is that these activities are consuming too much time.

How should the project manager handle this situation?

In the middle of an iteration, the product owner tells the agile team that the government has updated legal requirements. This will result in some changes in the product definition.

How should the project manager handle this situation?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
When there are significant changes in legal requirements that affect the product definition, it is crucial to reassess the current iteration backlog to ensure that the team is working on the most up-to-date and compliant requirements. This reassessment helps to identify any necessary adjustments and prioritize the work accordingly, ensuring that the project remains aligned with the new legal requirements.

Selected Answer: C
C. Review the iteration backlog because the product definition has changed and needs to be reassessed before continuing the project

Selected Answer: C
Review the iteration backlog because the product definition has changed and needs to be reassessed before continuing the project.
This option ensures that the team addresses the changes immediately and integrates them into the current iteration in a way that maintains compliance and aligns with the updated product definition. It involves the product owner and the team reassessing and reprioritizing the iteration backlog, ensuring that the project remains on track and meets the necessary legal requirements.

choices.C: Review the iteration backlog because the product definition has changed and needs to be reassessed before continuing the project.

choices.B: Ask the product owner to add new changes to the bottom of the backlog in order to handle the modifications as a change request.
choices.D: Ask a business analyst to assess the changes and then add/remove the stories in the backlog and prioritize them by business value.

choices.C: Assess all of the project stakeholders and document their preferred communication method and frequency.
choices.A: Hold a steering committee meeting with all stakeholders to provide a comprehensive update on the project progress.
choices.D: Include stakeholders in the weekly status meetings with the team.
choices.B: Create daily progress reports and send them to all stakeholders.

It's important to understand how each stakeholder prefers to receive information and how often they want updates. By documenting these preferences, the project manager can tailor communication to meet the needs of each stakeholder, ensuring that everyone is properly informed about the project's progress. This approach helps to build trust and ensures that stakeholders feel engaged and informed throughout the project.

A project manager has just taken over a project that is in the requirements gathering phase. A stakeholder indicates that they have not received any progress updates even though reports have been sent on a weekly basis.

What should the project manager do to ensure all stakeholders are receiving proper information about the project?

A project manager is managing a new development program to automate some technical functions. During project kickoff, the project manager expresses the need for a technical architect to support the project for a moderate amount of time. The project sponsor informs the project manager about an existing technical architect who possesses valuable knowledge but is already assigned at the portfolio level.

What engagement model should the project manager use for the technical architect role to ensure project success?

choices.A: Share the existing technical architect so they can be allocated to the current project and other projects.
choices.D: Assign the existing technical architect to solely be dedicated to the current project.
choices.B: Hire a new technical architect who would be solely dedicated to the current project.
choices.C: Hire a new technical architect who would be shared between the current project and other projects.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Sharing the existing technical architect allows the project to benefit from their valuable knowledge and expertise while still maintaining their involvement at the portfolio level. This approach ensures that the technical architect's skills are utilized effectively across multiple projects, promoting collaboration and consistency in technical decisions

Selected Answer: A
A. Share the existing technical architect so they can be allocated to the current project and other projects
